title: Unit 1 Checkpoint: Limits & Continuity
description: Unit test covering all limit and continuity topics: limits from graphs/tables, algebraic limit techniques, one-sided and infinite limits, limits at infinity, continuity, IVT, and Squeeze Theorem. Includes FRQ-style questions requiring written justification.

remediationStrategy.description: Students scoring below threshold receive focused reteaching on weak skill clusters before advancing to Unit 2 (Derivatives).

clusters.reteachFocus: Factoring 0/0 forms, rationalizing conjugates, special trig limits
Sign analysis near vertical asymptotes, piecewise one-sided limits
Degree comparison, leading coefficient ratio, radical expressions at infinity
Three conditions for continuity, classifying discontinuities, piecewise parameter problems
Writing complete IVT justifications with hypotheses and conclusion

assessmentProblems.question: For f(x) = (2x+1)/(x²-9), find: (a) lim(x→3⁺) f(x), (b) lim(x→3⁻) f(x), (c) lim(x→-3) f(x), (d) all vertical asymptotes.
For f(x) = {x² + 2, x < 1; ax + b, 1 ≤ x < 4; 2x - 3, x ≥ 4}, find a and b so that f is continuous on (-∞, ∞).
assessmentProblems.answer: At x=1: lim left = 1+2=3. f(1) = a+b. Set a+b=3. At x=4: lim left = 4a+b. f(4)=8-3=5. Set 4a+b=5. Subtract: 3a=2 → a=2/3. b=3-2/3=7/3.

assessmentProblems.question: (FRQ-style) A function f is continuous on [-2, 5] with the following values: f(-2) = 4, f(0) = -1, f(3) = 2, f(5) = 6. (a) Must there exist a value c in (-2, 5) where f(c) = 0? Justify using a theorem. (b) Must there exist a value c in (0, 5) where f(c) = 3? Justify. (c) Can you guarantee a value where f(c) = 7?
assessmentProblems.answer: (a) Yes. f is continuous on [-2, 0]. f(-2)=4 > 0 and f(0)=-1 < 0. By IVT, there exists c in (-2, 0) where f(c) = 0. (b) Yes. f is continuous on [0, 5]. f(0)=-1 < 3 and f(5)=6 > 3. By IVT, there exists c in (0, 5) where f(c) = 3. (c) No. f(5) = 6 < 7, and we have no value where f > 7. IVT cannot guarantee this.

assessmentProblems.question: Given that -x⁴ ≤ x⁴·cos(5/x²) ≤ x⁴ for x ≠ 0, evaluate lim(x→0) x⁴·cos(5/x²).
assessmentProblems.answer: lim(x→0) (-x⁴) = 0 and lim(x→0) x⁴ = 0. By Squeeze Theorem: lim(x→0) x⁴·cos(5/x²) = 0.

assessmentProblems.question: (FRQ) The function g is defined on [-3, 5] and its graph consists of a semicircle of radius 2 centered at (0, 0) for -2 ≤ x ≤ 2, with g(-3) = 0 and g(5) = -1, connected by line segments. Use the graph to find: (a) lim(x→2⁻) g(x), (b) lim(x→2⁺) g(x), (c) Is g continuous at x = 2? Explain.
assessmentProblems.answer: (a) From the semicircle (upper half): at x=2, y = √(4-4) = 0. lim(x→2⁻) g(x) = 0. (b) From the line segment from (2, 0) to (5, -1): slope = (-1-0)/(5-2) = -1/3. At x=2: g = 0. lim(x→2⁺) g(x) = 0. (c) lim(x→2⁻)=0, lim(x→2⁺)=0, so lim(x→2) g(x) = 0. If g(2)=0, then g is continuous at x=2. All three conditions met: g(2) defined, limit exists, limit = g(2).

assessmentProblems.question: SPIRAL: Evaluate lim(x→0) (eˣ - 1)/x. [Hint: This is the derivative definition of eˣ at x=0.]
assessmentProblems.answer: Direct substitution: 0/0. This equals lim(h→0) (e^(0+h) - e⁰)/h = d/dx[eˣ] at x=0 = e⁰ = 1. (Alternatively, use L'Hôpital preview: d/dx[eˣ]/d/dx[x] = eˣ/1 → e⁰ = 1.)

answerKeys.cu1-7: (a) Yes, IVT on [-2,0] (b) Yes, IVT on [0,5] (c) No
